results.abstract: Mario Andretti to cut tics with Britain-based Lotus auto racing team at end of '80 season; refuses to name team he will join (M)

headline.main: Andretti to Cut Ties With Lotus; Chip Off the Old Block Lotus Becomes Obsolete He Remains Noncommittal Qualifying Record Is Surpassed

results.snippet: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 4-- Mario Andretti, who won the World Championship of Drivers in 1978 in a Lotus, says he has had it with the Britain-based team. As the 1980 Grand Prix season winds down to its finish here this weekend, Andretti has let it...

byline.original: By JOHN S. RADOSTA Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 4-- Mario Andretti, who won the World Championship of Drivers in 1978 in a Lotus, says he has had it with the Britain-based team. As the 1980 Grand Prix season winds down to its finish here this weekend, Andretti has let it be known he will switch to another team next year.

headline.main: ANDRETTI TO CUT TIES WITH LOTUS

results.snippet: Mario Andretti, who won the World Championship of Drivers in 1978 in a Lotus, says he has had it with the Britain-based team. As the 1978 Grand Prix season winds down to its finish here this weekend, Andretti has let it be known he will switch to...
results.lead_paragraph: Mario Andretti, who won the World Championship of Drivers in 1978 in a Lotus, says he has had it with the Britain-based team. As the 1978 Grand Prix season winds down to its finish here this weekend, Andretti has let it be known he will switch to another team next year. Andretti said today he did not want to violate a confidence by identifying his new affiliation. The consensus, though, is that he will go with Alfa-Romeo of Italy.

results.abstract: Ryumin and Popov return safely to earth after record 185 days in orbit aboard Salyut space station; both reported in good health; Popov is awarded title of Hero of the Soviet Union and Ryumin the Order of Lenin; some experiments performed by cosmonauts noted; their portrait (M)

headline.main: SOVIET ASTRONAUTS END RECORD FLIGHT; Tass Says Two Made Safe Landing After 185-Day Space Mission in Salyut 6 Orbiting Craft 'Pleasant to a Have Soft Landing' Doubt About Foreign Contribution American Lack May Be Soviet Gain

results.snippet: MOSCOW, Oct. 11--Two Soviet astronauts, Leonid I. Popov and Valery V. Ryumin, returned to earth today after setting a record of 185 days in space flight aboard the orbiting station Salyut 6.

byline.original: By ANTHONY AUSTIN Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 11--Two Soviet astronauts, Leonid I. Popov and Valery V. Ryumin, returned to earth today after setting a record of 185 days in space flight aboard the orbiting station Salyut 6.

headline.main: Longer Space Trips Are Feasible, Russian Says After Record Flight

results.snippet: Valery V. Ryumin, a Soviet astronaut who returned to earth Saturday after a record 185 days in space, said today that he thought man was capable of even longer missions and that he would willingly fly to Mars.         Interviewed by Tass, the...
results.lead_paragraph: Valery V. Ryumin, a Soviet astronaut who returned to earth Saturday after a record 185 days in space, said today that he thought man was capable of even longer missions and that he would willingly fly to Mars. Interviewed by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, Mr. Ryumin said he thought men could endure far longer spells in space if the mission had a concrete aim.

results.abstract: John Noble Wilford on divergent paths being followed by US and USSR toward orbiting of permanent space station; discusses US concentration on space shuttle and Soviet Salyut project; drawings; photo of Popov and Ryumin (M)

headline.main: MAJOR POWERS TRAVEL ALONG DIVERGENT PATHS TOWARD LIFE IN ORBIT

results.snippet: SINCE the last American flew in space, back in July 1975, the Soviet Union has sent three dozen astronauts into Earth orbit, broken all flight endurance records and encouraged speculation that in a few years it would be operating the science fiction...
results.lead_paragraph: SINCE the last American flew in space, back in July 1975, the Soviet Union has sent three dozen astronauts into Earth orbit, broken all flight endurance records and encouraged speculation that in a few years it would be operating the science fiction buff's dream - an orbital station designed for permanent occupation. At the same time, the United States has concentrated on its reusable shuttle, which has yet to fly, but will reestablish a frequent American presence in manned Earth orbital flights. The two programs point up the divergent paths that the superpowers are taking, although they share a common goal of achieving everyday life in space near Earth.

results.abstract: Ryumin says he believes man is capable of even longer missions (S)

headline.main: Longer Space Trips Are Feasible, Russian Says After Record Flight

results.snippet: MOSCOW, Oct. 13 (Reuters)--Valery V. Ryumin, a Soviet astronaut who returned to earth Saturday after a record 185 days in space, said today that he thought man was capable of even longer missions and that he would willingly fly to Mars.
results.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 13 (Reuters)--Valery V. Ryumin, a Soviet astronaut who returned to earth Saturday after a record 185 days in space, said today that he thought man was capable of even longer missions and that he would willingly fly to Mars.
